pageContext.description: Broken in two. at A+B are indications as of a rather roughly woven textile with slight remains of red colour. At A and again at C + D.
pageContext.other: Width: blade 37mm; 47mm; socket end 25mm,Thickness: blade 16mm; 14mm,weight: 127.56 gms
pageContext.associations: Probably found with socketed celt (and another spearhead ? - probably not),1860
pageContext.publications: R. L.L. Kenyon, Shropshire Arch. Trans. IV (2nd S), 279.,Ander, Vic. Co. Hist. I 202,A "spear from Child's Ercall" was No. 39 in Exhibition of Shrops. Antiqs. 1898 (S.A.T. X 2nd S, 108)
pageContext.collection: Shrewsbury Museum,donor H. R. Corbet, Esq.
pageContext.toSearch: Child's Ercall, Market Drayton, Shropshire Tf9, UK
pageContext.remarks: Shrewsbury Museum Donations Book I (Mus) records that, on July 29th 188, H. R. Corbet, Esq., of Adderley, presented "1 Bronze Roman Celt, found in the parish of Child's Ercall, Salop, 1858," and "1 Roman Bronze Spear or Banner Head found at the same place" [Presumably this one as its patination is more like that of the celt than the other specimen labelled as from this site.]
